title: 111_s3927
content: The Act may be cited as the "Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta National Heritage Area Establishment Act". This Act establishes the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta National Heritage Area. The Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta Heritage Area is established in California with defined boundaries in specific counties. The management entity will develop and adopt a management plan for the area. The Secretary of the Interior is involved in overseeing the Heritage Area. The Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta National Heritage Area in California includes specific counties and is managed by the Delta Protection Commission. The management entity will develop a management plan for the area, overseen by the Secretary of the Interior. The management entity for the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta National Heritage Area in California must submit a proposed management plan to the Secretary for approval in accordance with the Omnibus Public Land Management Act of 2009. The management plan for the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta National Heritage Area must ensure participation from various agencies and stakeholders, and cannot be approved without certification from the Delta Protection Commission. The Delta Stewardship Council reviewed the Heritage Area management plan for consistency with the plan adopted by the Council. The provisions of the Omnibus Public Land Management Act of 2009 apply to the Heritage Area, including its relationship to other federal agencies and private property. The provisions of section 8001(f) and 8001(g) of the Omnibus Public Land Management Act of 2009 apply to the Heritage Area. Property owners can opt out of participating in activities within the area by providing written notice to the management entity. Nothing in this section affects the designation of the Heritage Area. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the Heritage Area, with $20,000,000 authorized for implementation, and a maximum of $2,000,000 available per fiscal year. The Federal share of costs for activities will not exceed 50 percent, with non-Federal partners required to contribute the remaining share. The non-Federal share of costs for activities in the Heritage Area can be in the form of in-kind contributions or State/local government fees. If a management plan is not submitted within 5 years of enactment, the Heritage Area designation will be rescinded.
